intro: Rubachia lateriflora, commonly known as the side-flowered rubachia, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale pink flowers arranged in dense, spherical clusters called umbels. It typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and wetlands. Rubachia lateriflora is often found in the understory of forests, where it thrives in partial shade.
